awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Southern San Andreas Fault Zone Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
The San Andreas Fault (SAF) in California is a mature plate boundary fault capable of great (magnitude 8 or greater) earthquakes. The southern section of the SAF has not produced a major earthquake in historic times (over the last 300 years), and is currently believed to pose the largest seismic risk in California. This project will use new seismic and geodetic observations to investigate the sub-surface structure and geometry of the Southern San Andreas Fault (SSAF). In particular, the project will test a hypothesis that the SSAF may not be vertical and may substantial dip to the East. If confirmed, a non-vertical fault dip would have important implications for the mechanics and the long-term tectonic evolution of the SSAF. Better knowledge of the sub-surface geometry of the SSAF will also improve  predictions of seismic radiation patterns and the intensity of ground shaking due to future large earthquakes on the SSAF. The broader impacts of this work will be refined estimates of seismic hazard in densely populated areas in Southern California and Mexico as well as support for the education of two graduate students.

The researchers from this joint project between the University of California San Diego, Scripps Institution of Oceanography and the University of Southern California, will investigate the fault attitude at depth by imaging a low-rigidity damage zone and/or a bi-material interface associated with the SSAF in the upper crust. This will be accomplished by deploying a dense seismic array spanning the SSAF. Data from the deployed seismic array and regional seismic networks will be used to generate high-resolution tomographic images of the fault zone throughout the seismogenic layer. Seismic data will be combined with high-resolution geodetic observations, including Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) and Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS). A joint analysis of seismic and geodetic data will provide new insights into the spatial extent and degree of damage around a mature plate boundary fault and enable comparisons with observations from other faults in California and elsewhere to examine how the distribution and amount of damage might depend on the fault age, seismic potential, and geometric complexity. The deployment of co-located dense seismic and geodetic arrays will establish a baseline for future measurements of possible time-dependent variations in mechanical properties of rocks comprising the fault zone due to external stress perturbations, which may help constrain the magnitude of absolute stress at seismogenic depth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project is to test the hypothesis that the Southern San Andreas Fault (SSAF) may not be vertical but rather have a substantial dip to the northeast. To test this hypothesis, we have been analyzing geometrical properties of fault structure data in high-resolution seismic catalog, tomographic velocity models, receiver functions, and dedicated seismic deployment aiming to image a low-rigidity damage zone and/or a bimaterial interface associated with the SSAF in the upper crust. Results based on analyses of seismological data done by the USC group were combined with geodetic observations by the UCSD group to place robust constraints on the subsurface geometry and mechanical properties of SSAF. The two groups worked together on synthesizing the seismic and geodetic results.

The seismological investigations included the development of several new techniques and focused on the following research directions. (1) Developing and implementing an eikonal tomography based on noise correlations to image the plate boundary region in Southern California and examining dipping fault structures in the results. (2) Using high resolution seismic catalogs and receiver function analysis to resolve dipping geometries of the main faults in Southern California. (3) Conducting a dense nodal seismic deployment across the SSAF in the Thousand Palms Canyon area. The field experiment had 339 nodes deployed with ~15 m spacing long a line crossing the Mission Creek and Banning branches of the SSAF in the area, with mini 2D arrays around the intersection of the line with the two fault branches. The analyses of the dense deployment data included imaging the structure of the SSAF using signals generated by trains and trucks, analysis of seismic waves across the array, and reverse-time migration of direct P and fault zone reflected waves.

The investigations provided high-resolution results on seismic properties of the SSAF in the Thousand Palms Canyon are, including significant contrasts of seismic velocity and mass density across the Mission Creek branch of the SSAF. The results demonstrated that both the Banning and Mission Creek branches of the SSAF dip about 70 deg to the NE in the top 3 km of the crust. The seismic and geodetic and observations suggest jointly that the relatively straight section of the SSAF, between Thousand Palms and Bombay Beach, is dipping to the northeast at 60-80 degrees throughout the entire upper crust. The results suggest further that the Mission Creek fault is the main active branch of the SSAF in the Thousand Palms area.

The project supported several graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. Participation in the project provided the students, postdocs, and early career researchers experience with field work and state-of-the art analysis techniques of seismic and geodetic data. The research combined with work on papers and meeting abstracts, as well as conference talks and discussions in meetings, contributed further to the professional development of the participants. The project results have been presented in conferences, published in peer-reviewed journals, and posted on the websites of the PI and other participants.


Last Modified: 06/05/2023
Modified by: Yehuda Ben-Zion
